dialogues.text: Gin is gin... you know Percy can’t count and drink at the same time.
She know she ain’t even driving, already complaining about somethin’. What you need to do is put that boy to bed.
What you need to do is mind your business and get what’s coming to ya. I’ll clear it, Mama. Elwood, get down now.
I said I’d do the washing up, Mama.
At least tell the child you’re leaving.

dialogues.text: The first order of business in my class will be to strike out all the bad words they left for you.
September is the tutorial in the latest epithets of white youth, which like hemlines and haircuts vary from year to year, and are quite imaginative. SOUND of a ruffling.
Mr. Hill, you a Freedom Rider?
That how you got that scar over your eye?
Nashville. White man slugged me with a tire iron. (CONTINUED) 11.

dialogues.text: Hi Elwood. I came to see you. (beat) Don’t worry, good news.

This fall at least, so word gets out in the community.
(with barely contained excitement) I’ll have to ask my grandmother-

You eat that oatmeal like your mama made it.
I ain’t never seen someone eat this food like that- like they liked it.
I don’t know why you so loud, you know they got their eye on you this week.
I’m from Houston myself. That’s a real city. None of this country shit y’all got up here. CONTINUED: 54

dialogues.text: Thought you’d be done after the last time.
(terrified) I’m-a hold on and be s-s-s-s-s-s-st- I’m-a hold on and be st-st-still. SOUND of Corey sobbing as they drag Black Mike out.

scenes.actionPreview: 65 65 Elwood POV as they enter. The stench is fierce. Urine, feces and fear are soaked into the concrete and they all react to it as they enter. dialogues.text: Hold on to the rail and don’t let go. Shhhh. Don’t make a sound. (pause) You’ll get more.

dialogues.text: Sat down to dinner at that guard’s house once. Roast beef. His wife made an angel food cake. I was in the scouts with his sons. He taught us how to make a fire.

dialogues.text: That don’t bode well. I can’t help it if we don’t got every can of beans he asked for.
Ten for stress. I got my draft notice this morning. You’re lucky to be in Nickel.

scenes.heading: INT. NICKEL ACADEMY - INFIRMARY - 1966 - DAY (D42)
scenes.actionPreview: 74 74 Elwood POV lying on his stomach on the bed. He can hear Nurse Scarlett coming, her shoes squeaking on the linoleum tiles and her uniform making a scratching sound. Her white shoes and panty-hosed legs walk back forth, as she collects bedpans and brings clean ones to the few other patients on t

scenes.heading: EXT. NICKEL ACADEMY - GROUNDS - 1966 - DAY (D43)

dialogues.text: Young man, do you know a student named Elwood Curtis?
I’ve come all this way... it’s a crime to keep me from him, a crime. (beat) I don’t know what kind of place this is, I don’t understand why they can’t let me see him.
Nice to know I can count on somebody round here, Turner.
When’s the last time you had family visit, Turner?
(looking down) ...They... well, my kin, my parents, I mean my ma, she...
Well I came all this way. I can’t hug Elwood, so you’ll have to do.
What are they feeding you all in here? I know you can muster a better hug than that.
I’ll expect it the next time,

scenes.actionPreview: 75 75 SOUND of a lawnmower, louder and louder as it approaches. Turner POV as he walks along a path that winds through the campus. On the grass alongside him, a WHITE BOY pushes a hand mower into frame, keeping pace, messing with him. The noise is deafening. An older Black woman walks past them, dem

scenes.heading: INT. NICKEL ACADEMY - INFIRMARY - 1966 - DAY (D43)

dialogues.text: How you making out here, hero?
There’s four ways out of Nickel and you were almost awarded one for “ineffective heroism”.
How you like that witch doctor.
Come in here with your damn head cut off and he’d give you aspirin.
Come in here, head cut off, both legs, both arms cut off, and that witch doctor would be like, ‘You want one tablet, or two?’
Ate some soap powder, an hour of stomach ache for a whole day off.
Aren’t you worried they’ll know you’re faking it? Whistling happy like that?
I ain’t faking- that soap powder is awful. But it’s me choosing, not anyone else.
Turner, you again? I told you not to eat the food!
What else am I supposed to eat,
Go look. See who it is. Ask what’s wrong with him.
I ain’t asking nobody shit. CONTINUED: (2) 76
Damn, you don’t know. Pop back there for a look, maybe you have to trade places with him. Like in a ghost story.
(quietly; confessing) I never been sent down to the White
I have a lawyer. He can do something.
Sometimes they throw you in Hell. A sweatbox up in the eaves below that tar roof. Sweat your soul outta you.
Sometimes they take you and we never see your ass again. CONTINUED: (3) 76
Your family asks the school what happened and they say you ran away. I’ll show you sometime, show you something that’s not in books, where it is. Boot Hill.
Problem is Elwood, you didn’t know how it works. You wanted to do some
I saw his face, he was scared.
You don’t know what makes him tick.
If everyone looks the other way, then everybody’s in on it. If I look the other way, I’m as implicated as the rest.
It’s not how it’s supposed to be.
Don’t nobody care about s’posed to.
That shit barely works out there- what do you think it’s going to do in here?
You say that because there’s no one out there sticking up for you. I got my grandmother, I got a lawyer.
Walk out of here. You think you can do that? Watch and think and plan?

dialogues.text: Boys, you gotta toughen up. Spider bite, busted ankle, what’s next?
Harper. Mr. Harper sir. We’re short of hands.
Well we’re short of hands too, son.

scenes.actionPreview: 81 81 Elwood POV waiting with a group of boys as the old tractor that will haul them out to the fields in the wooden trailer backs up toward them. Blakeley is lecturing them. The count’s been off. We can’t have those inspectors coming out here thinking that y’all are lazy or that I’m not working you

scenes.heading: INT. COMMUNITY SERVICE VAN - NICKEL ACADEMY - 1966 - DAY

dialogues.text: Turner here says you can keep your mouth shut, and that you’re not a math dummy.
It’s taking things and making sure they end up where they’re supposed to end up in the end.
Sometimes the State gives us more than we strictly need. So we pass it on.
It used to be worse in the old days, from what my aunt says. But the State cracked down and now we only lay off the south campus stuff.
You mean the Negro students’ stuff.
We had this good ole boy who used to run Nickel, Roberts, who would’ve sold the air you breathe if he could’ve. Now that was a crook!
It had to end up somewhere.
Beats the fields. If you ask me.
Beats getting mangled in a machine.

dialogues.text: My Aunt Mavis made sure I had nice clothes for school and three meals.
I guess I wouldn’t want them to visit, either. (pause) What about your real father?

A guy at the Houston airport started seeing her. He taught me how to box. The day I put myself between Aunt Mavis and his fist, he took

scenes.heading: EXT. HARDEE HOUSE - PORCH - MARIANNA - 1966 - DAY (D51)

dialogues.text: Thank you, Mrs. Hardee, don’t mind if I do.
My great-grandfather built this place 106 years ago. My husband proposed to me right there. CONTINUED: 88
You boys are so nice to help us out here.
Oh, almost forgot, I have a box of books to donate to the Nickel library.
We can help you with that.
The box is in the garage-
My grandma once lent me out for ten cents to give Mrs. Lamont’s outhouse a new coat.
Used to be worse around here. When you graduated you didn’t go back to your family, you had parole and they sold your monkey ass to people in the town. You had to work off your debt.
I never thought about it that way. CONTINUED: 90
All those guys on the school board have us do chores. Sometimes it’s favors, sometimes it’s for real money.
The law’s one thing. You can march and wave signs around and change a law if you convince enough white people. I saw the college kids in
My grandma got me that lawyer, man.
The courts play both the white and the black. They move us around when they ready. CONTINUED: (2) 90
We have to be knights. Checkmate.
How many people done that, El? Only four ways outta Nickel.
A hour late. Fly still open.

scenes.actionPreview: 90 90 Turner’s POV as he and Elwood paint the weathered, faded grey floorboards of a long porch than runs along the back of a big pink house with white trim and pillars. A sparkling blue swimming pool floats in a lush green lawn surrounded by banana trees, palms and a few pool umbrellas. An American

dialogues.text: A British mother is trying to marry off her oldest daughter to keep their estate and title.
No one wants to marry her? She ugly?
She’s described as having a handsome face.
I know my mother loved me. She just loved liquor more.

dialogues.text: She says she visited and they wouldn’t let her see me. (reading) “He’s sick and can’t have no visitors.” “What’s wrong with him?” “How the hell should I know, lady?” (freaking out completely) How can they do that! Sick?

Do you think he’ll knock him down? CUT TO:
Turner, that’s a hundred dollar bill! CUT TO:
Yep. Fat cats from all three counties. Stakes get higher every year. CUT TO:

Damn. You don’t think... Griff could knock out Big Chet by accident? CUT TO:
Jab! Jab! Roll that shoulder. Left, left hook, Griff!
Witchdoctor give him the whole bucket of aspirin and he’ll still have a headache! WHITE BOY 3 (O.S.)
He’s making it look good for sure.
He’s putting a hurt on that white boy at least before he goes down, makes me feel all right.
(stuttering) KKKkkk’s gonna be crying under their hoods all week!

dialogues.text: It’s been a long wait for some good news.
I’m sure Melvin Briggs will have you. And those books you were reading ain’t gone nowhere.
I’ve been taking less work and spending more time at the church.
Nanna, what is it? What’s wrong?
El, he’s gone. Mr. Andrews, you know, our lawyer who’s so optimistic about your appeal- I went downtown to see him, I took the bus. I had paid him $200 which wasn’t enough. CONTINUED: 110
You mean he’s gone... he didn’t... after all this time...
The landlord was showing the office to a dentist. When I asked for Mr.
I’m okay Nanna. I’m hanging in there.
You got any friends? How about
(oblivious) I didn’t know how I was gonna get you that package, that day-
(oblivious) -and there he was. I like him, he’s polite, looked me in the eye. That was a real kindness...

scenes.heading: EXT. NICKEL ACADEMY - GROUNDS - 1967 - DAY (D61)

dialogues.text: I’m sorry, El. I don’t know why I didn’t give you that letter. I guess I was...

dialogues.text: Elwood this might be solid brass, man. (beat) I got dibs on this.

dialogues.text: We don’t got to make a scene, but yeah.

So I’d head out here into the free world, snatch clothes from a wash line. Head South, because they ain’t expecting it. Put as many miles between me and the dogs as I can, tire them out. The trick is not doing what they
Yeah, well why wouldn’t they know you trying not to do what they think you going to-
-and don’t take no one with you.

scenes.actionPreview: 115 115 Elwood POV is under a portico, looking up at himself and Turner in the reflective surface of its underside. Don’t look scared. scenes.heading: EXT. MAIN STREET SIDEWALK - MARIANNA - 1967 - DAY (D62)

dialogues.text: What happened to not making a scene? You think Rev’rend King’s out here in Mariana opening supermarkets?
Our ‘community service’ (beat) The deliveries, the pay-offs, the yard work, the chores. The names of everybody and the dates.
Why would you do a thing like that?
You told me. No one else can get me out of here, just me. CONTINUED: 115A
Nobody ever listens to me, why you got to start?
I get it, you mad and need to get it off your chest, that’s cool, but-
-I’m telling you. There’s a fifth way out: Get. Rid. Of. Nickel.
They put us in the goddamn ground!

dialogues.text: This rat ran across my feet and I screamed. That was me.
Denise. Hathor. Scared of a little ole rodent.
Sh-, was big as a dog. (beat)

Found one, a ‘67 Econoline. Needs a new finish, but the guys on 125th owe me one. I can supplement the

Not sure yet, something easy to find in the Yellow Pages.
There’s some rum in that. I got us some sandwiches, too.

You should watch what you say, El. (beat) I’d marry Sidney Poitier. ARCHIVAL FOOTAGE - 1970S 119

dialogues.text: It’s me, man, Pete Evans... Chickie
Damn. Shit man. Been ages! Beer? On me?
(shifting to stand) I got an early morning-
Naw naw man, you gotta let me buy you a beer.
...I mighta played professional, if things had been different.
... I coulda been in a funk band, an orch-est-ra! Ha. Haydn, Bach
It’s how I got started cooking.
I just spent 30 days drying out.
It’s okay I can handle it now. I always drank. Then it was like the more I tried to settle down, the more I got blotto every night.
I got a moving company, trucks, employees.
My man! Moving on up! You got a lady?
No. I mean, I did, but it didn’t work out. “Denise.” She said I had a lotta work to do on myself.
I hear you, I hear you. Hard to find somebody who could understand.
Yeah, I’m still looking for the “one”. Maybe some day.
You seen any of the guys? I’ve ran into some over the years. Black

What? Shit, I remember what they did to Griff. Sshhitt. What they did to me. (beat) When they stuffed that kid in the big dryer. (dark chuckle to himself) And the one they made eat a lightbulb, ha. You know what I remember?! The effing ghost... man, slipping on skin, flesh, whatever the hell it was in the shower. Yeah. What else you want me to remember?
(gate firmly shut) -Nothing. Time served. And they kicked me out. (beat) I went up to
Yeah, that’s nice. Everybody’s welcomed here... what happened to that kid you used to hang around with all the time?
The kid, you know- y’all thought that hiding place was so secret.
Gotta take a leak, it’ll come back to me.
No no, I hear you, me too. (pause) I don’t want to ask. But if you’re looking for a hand, I could use the job. I’m sleeping on a couch.
I can handle the work, is what I’m putting out there.
You ring me up- for the old days.

What you think they going to do?

This is just one place. There are
How long we got to keep murdering ourselves?!

dialogues.text: I need you to head up to the farms and find Mr. Gladwell. Those men from the State aren’t heading up there today. They’re going to send some other experts for that. You find him and tell him he can relax.
(talking too fast) I like the bleacher repair. We still need to paint, too. Can one of the little kids go? CONTINUED: 131
(CONTINUED) 105. I don’t even know what Mr. Gladwell looks like, Mr. Harper, sir.
That notebook you got in your pocket. I’ll get it to them, I’ll do it. Look at you, you look sick.
I can slip it in their car window when they’re not looking. They won’t even see. CUT TO:

Didn’t she leave you for another man?
Shit’s not funny guys, I ain’t seen my kids in six months.
Fold. (meaning the queen) And there she is. Careful Earl.
